abstract.p: The nonlinear dynamic characteristics of a simple three-bus power system mathematic model are studied, including phase diagrams and a bifurcation map. To control this undesirable chaos, sliding mode control law without buffeting is presented based on the LaSalle invariance principle, which considers the bounded disturbances. The theoretical analysis is in agreement with numerical simulation in that the designed controller could asymptotically stabilize the unstable power system to a typical steady-state. The research of this paper may help to maintain the power system's security operation.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Chaos, a nonlinear phenomenon, has been intensively investigated in medical science (Ye and Ding, 2009), biology (Zhang et al., 2010), and physics (Zhang and Small, 2006), etc. As the chaotic state in most systems is harmful, thus chaos control is of great help. Chaos control is disquisitive in how to control the chaotic system to the periodic orbit or equilibrium point with the original parameters being remained or only fine-tuned when the system parameters cannot be changed objectively, or the parameters change largely must pay a great price. Typical control methods have been proposed to achieve chaos control. Romeiras et al. (1992) describe a method that converts the motion on a chaotic attractor to a desired attracting time periodic motion by making only small time dependent perturbations of a control parameter. Chen et al. (2011b) proposed a no-chattering sliding mode control method for the Hindmarsh-Rose model with uncertain parameters and bounded external disturbances. Chen et al. (2011a) also investigated the chaos control of a class of fractional-order chaotic systems via sliding mode. Sudheer and Sabir (2011) consider modified function projectivesynchronization of unidirectionally coupled multiple time-delayed Rossler chaotic systems using adaptive controls. An integral-type sliding mode controller design for generalized projective synchronization of two horizontal platform systems (HPS) is considered by Pai and Yau (2011). Based on the Ott, Grelogi and York approach, a multiparameter semi-continuous method was designed by de Paula and Savi (2009) to control chaotic behavior. Loria (2010) solves the problem of chaos suppression of Lu’s hyper-chaotic system via feedback control.

In essence, the energy resource system is a strongly nonlinear large-scale system. Oscillations of energy resources system are injurious to the system’s security and stability. For example, in 1966, oscillations occurred six times in 1 min soon after American Northwest Power System and Southwest Power System interconnected, which resulted in the two systems splitting (Yu, 1983). Under certain conditions, the energy resource system can engender complete chaos, which causes electromechanical oscillations to behave randomly, and even the system voltage to collapse, or to the system splitting in a serious case (Revel et al., 2010). Thus chaos control of energy resource systems has practical significance.

Chaos research in the field of energy resources systems began in the early 1980s. American mathematicians Kopell and Washburn. (1982) studied the chaos of a three-machine system by means of the Melnikov method, and created this new area. Chiang et al. (1993) investigated the chaotic behavior and bifurcation of a three-bus system by numerical methods in detail. Shi and Wang (2010) investigated the robust chaos synchronization problem for the four-dimensional energy resource systems with mismatched parameters. Huang et al. (2011) proposes a chaos synchronization based detector for power-quality disturbances classification in a power system. Recently, the research of energy resource system has attracted increasing attention (Huang et al., 2009; Sun et al., 2009a,b; Lai and Swarup, 2011; Wei et al., 2011). For its advantages, such as robustness to parameter uncertainty, insensitivity to bounded disturbances, fast dynamic response, a remarkable computational simplicity with respect to other robust control approaches, and easy implementation of the controller, the sliding mode method is applied to control energy resources system with bounded disturbances to a stability state in this paper.

The outline of this paper is as follows: Section 2 describes simply the model. Section 3 discusses the dynamics behavior of the system. Section 4 presents the sliding control of the system. Section 5 gives numerical results. Section 6 summarizes this work.

sec.p:
A simple three-bus power system is illustrated in Figure1. This power system is composed of two generator buses and a load bus. One of the generator buses is treated as a slack bus (Chiang et al., 1993). The other generator bus is described by the swing equation. sec.title: 3. The route to chaos of the power system
sec.p:
The bifurcation map is used to analyze the dynamic characteristics of the nonlinear system when the system parameter varies. Bifurcation is the main route to chaos from the stable state. It is known that the system parameter reactive power Q must change all the time and thesystem conditions can change when the system is disturbed by inevitable disturbances. Hence there is a possibility of the existence of chaos. And thus, the bifurcation map is shown as Figure 2 and the phase diagrams and timing diagrams are given in Figure 3 with the reactive power Q varying. Figure 2.
Bifurcation map with Q varying. Figure 3.
Phase diagrams and timing diagrams with Q varying.

From Figures 2 and 3, it is known that the dynamic behavior of the power system is complex and the system goes through a series of operating states when the reactive power Q increases. When the disturbance is small, the system oscillates and then may converge to a stable point due to damping. When the disturbance increases, the system can be chaotic. If the disturbance is larger, it may lead to a voltage collapse, angle instability or voltage collapse with angle divergence simultaneously. It appears that the chaotic system is a transient process and after then the system may be harmful to the stability of the whole system. In this paper, the existence of chaos and chaos control of the three-bus power system will be investigated.

sec.title: 4. Chaos analysis of the power system
4.1. Sensitive to initial conditions
sec.p:
As the motion of chaos is sensitively dependent on the initial conditions, the final movements of chaotic system can be quite distinct even with slight difference on the initial conditions. Here we choose initial conditions X1 = [0.3 0 0.2 0.97]T and X2 = X1 + [10−8,10−8,10−8,10−8]T when the reactive power Q = 11.3767. The timing diagrams of different initial conditions are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Timing diagrams of different initial conditions.

sec.title: 4.2. Strange attractor
sec.p:
As shown, the time responses of a power system are so random that it seems impossible to predict the exact trajectories of the system. However, there exists regularity, order characteristics and certainty in the motion of chaos. Some phase diagrams are shown in Figure 5 to demonstrate the existence of a stable attractor. It is obvious that the motion is confined to some regions and we can conclude that the motion of chaos is quite different from the random motion in essence. Figure 5.
Two initial conditions moving to strange attractor.

sec.title: 4.3. Poincare map
sec.p:
The Poincare map is a classic technology of dynamical system analysis, and the occurrence of chaos can bedetermined by the distribution of cut points on the Poincare section. When the dense point on the Poincare section isflaky and structural, the system is chaotic. The Poincare map is shown in the plane x3 = 0.15, illustrated in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Poincare diagram.

From above, it can be concluded that the system appears chaotic. The chaotic system is confined to some certain regions, so the chaotic system is stable from an overall point of view. However when the power system operates on the chaotic condition, it is harmful to the stability and security of the whole system operation, since the system may come into the instability conditions directly and easily. Thus it is of great help to control the chaotic system.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion and discussion
sec.p: In this paper, we analyze the dynamic behavior of a four-dimensional system which is established based on a three-bus power system. And then the chaotic system is controlled to any fixed points precisely. Finally, some numerical simulations are provided to demonstrate the validity of the proposed control. With the transition being time short, the control process is more smooth and precise. Thus, the control method can guarantee the stability and reliability of the system.

Some new electromechanical plant needs to be studied to improve the proposed sliding mode controller, such as fuzzy sliding mode control, second-order sliding mode control and so on. The next research plan is that experimental application will be carried out to test the effectiveness of the present sliding mode controller.
